page.title: 19FROM 1938 TO 1985
page.content: {When Dr Eric Waud came to be the {doctor of Brafferton and Helperby in {l938 there were no street lights as {there are now and the only lighting {came from the telephone box.Electric {light had only been installed three {years ago and most people still had {oil lamps. { There was no mains water until just {before the outbreak of war and the {doctor himself had two water tanks at {his house, one for soft and one for {hard. There were very few lavatories {and most people relied upon earth {closets in their gardens. There was no {mains sewer until the late 1950s. { There were few cars but many pony {and traps. Shire horses were widely {used on the farms.There were several {tradesmen that have now gone:a {brewer,station-master,tailor,cobbler, {blacksmith,baker and maltster.
